Class Expenses

Expenses class that is used to manage a list of Expense objects.

Inheritance

The DirName property represents the name of the directory.

Property to store and access the file name.

Methods

Add(DateTime, Int32, Double, String)

Adds a new Expense object in the list of Expense. The id number is generated by default.

Declaration
public void Add(DateTime date, int category, double amount, string description)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.DateTime date

The date of the expense.
System.Int32 category

The category of the expense.
System.Double amount

The amount of the expense.
System.String description

The description of the expense.
Examples

The example shown below shows the usage of this method: 

Expenses e = new Expenses();

//Adds a new Expense object to the list of Expense.
e.Add(1/10/2018 12:00:00 AM, 10, 10, "hat (on credit)");

//Loops through the list of Expense that was populated by the constructor and that had a expense added to it. 
//Also outputs the description of each expense to the console.
foreach (Expense expense in e.List()){
    Console.WriteLine(enxpense.description);
}

Delete(Int32)

Deletes the Expense that matches the id given in the parameter.

Declaration
public void Delete(int Id)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Int32 Id

The id number of the expense that needs to be deleted.
Examples

The example shown below shows the usage of this method: 

Expenses e = new Expenses();

//Removes a Category object from the list of Category.
e.Delete(1);

//Loops through the list of Expense that was populated by the constructor by default and that had a expense removed from it.
//Also outputs the description of each expense to the console.
foreach (Expense expense in e.List()){
    Console.WriteLine(expense.description);
}

List()

Returns a list of Expenses that contains Expense objects.

Declaration
public List<Expense> List()
Returns
Type Description
System.Collections.Generic.List<Expense>

A list of Expense Objects.
Examples

The example shown below shows the usage of this method: 

Expenses e = new Expenses();

//Loops through the list of Expense that was populated by the constructor and outputs the description of each expense to the console.
foreach (Expense expense in e.List()){
    Console.WriteLine(expense.description);
}

ReadFromFile(String)

Reads from a file if it exists and populates the expenses accordingly. This method is used to stores values for properties of Expense by reading its values from a file. This is possible with a method which makes the file an XML document to be able to read and add data to the Expense properties. This method will also save the directory and file name for later usage. The file path, if any, needs to be valid in order to read from it.

Declaration
public void ReadFromFile(string filepath = null)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String filepath

The file path from which the method will read from. If it is not provided (null), its value will be set by default.
Examples

The example shown below shows the usage of this method: 

Expenses e = new Expenses();


//Calls method to read from filepath and store data in the expenses property.
e.ReadFromFile(String filepath);

//Loops through the list of Expense that was populated by the previous method and outputs the description of each expense to the console.
foreach (Expense expense in e.List()){
    Console.WriteLine(expense.description);
}
Exceptions
Type Condition
System.IO.FileNotFoundException

Thrown when FilePath does not exist. Exception in VerifyReadFromFileName(String, String) method
System.Exception

thrown when there was an error reading from the XML file.

SaveToFile(String)

Saves the Expense objects and properties by writing them to a file. This method is used to save the Expense objects from a list to a file. This is possible by evaluating every Expense object properties from a list and writing them to a XML file. It is necessary for the file path, if any, given in the parameter to be valid in order to write to it. Also, the Expense list should not be empty since no data will be saved in the file.

Declaration
public void SaveToFile(string filepath = null)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String filepath

The file path from which the method will write to. If it is not provided (null), its value will be set by default.
Examples

The example shown below shows the usage of this method: 

Expenses e = new Expenses();

//Calls method to write to file in filepath.
e.SaveToFile(String filepath);

//Calls method to read from filepath and store data in the expenses property to be able to see the output gotten from the previous method.
e.ReadFromFile(String filepath);

//Loops through the list of Expense that was populated by the previous method and outputs the description of each expense to the console.
foreach (Expense expense in e.List()){
    Console.WriteLine(expense.description);
}
Exceptions
Type Condition
System.Exception

Thrown when FilePath does not exist or when FilePath is read-only meaning that you cannot write in the file. Exception in VerifyWriteToFileName(String, String) method.
